articles.headline: Starbucks’s Tall Order: Tackle Systemic Racism in 4 Hours
articles.snippet: The coffee chain closed its U.S. stores for several hours to improve its image after the arrests of two black men at a store in Philadelphia brought heavy criticism.
articles.abstract: The coffee chain closed its U.S. stores for several hours to improve its image after the arrests of two black men at a store in Philadelphia brought heavy criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Starbucks, the scope of companywide anti-bias training on Tuesday was easy to measure. Roughly 175,000 employees at 8,000 locations pored over nearly 23,000 iPads, learning about the processing power of unconscious brains and the roots of unconscious bias.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams, Tiffany Hsu and John Eligon

articles.headline: The Profound Social Cost of American Exceptionalism
articles.snippet: Rich and technologically advanced, the United States continues to accept a degree of dysfunction that would be intolerable in any other rich society.
articles.abstract: Rich and technologically advanced, the United States continues to accept a degree of dysfunction that would be intolerable in any other rich society.
articles.lead_paragraph: When I wrote my first Economic Scene column six years ago, the unemployment rate languished at 8.2 percent as the job market painfully recovered from the jolt of the Great Recession. By last month, only 3.9 percent of working-age Americans who sought a job didn’t have one.

articles.headline: Missouri’s Governor, a Rising G.O.P. Star, Resigns Amid Scandal
articles.snippet: Mr. Greitens, once seen as a Republican superstar, stepped down. For months, as scandal unfolded around him, he had defiantly refused to quit.
articles.abstract: Mr. Greitens, once seen as a Republican superstar, stepped down. For months, as scandal unfolded around him, he had defiantly refused to quit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eric Greitens was a decorated Navy SEAL who served in Afghanistan and Iraq, the founder of a veterans’ charity in Missouri and a Rhodes scholar. Chiseled and charismatic, he was elected governor of Missouri and seen by his fellow Republicans as a potential superstar in the party, someone with the brains and political instincts to perhaps rise all the way to the White House.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Trump Asked Sessions to Retain Control of Russia Inquiry After His Recusal
articles.snippet: The attorney general is a key witness in the investigation into whether Mr. Trump tried to obstruct the Russia inquiry itself.
articles.abstract: The attorney general is a key witness in the investigation into whether Mr. Trump tried to obstruct the Russia inquiry itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time Attorney General Jeff Sessions arrived at President Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort for dinner one Saturday evening in March 2017, he had been receiving the presidential silent treatment for two days. Mr. Sessions had flown to Florida because Mr. Trump was refusing to take his calls about a pressing decision on his travel ban.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Negotiations in Italy Push Euro to Fore, the Last Place Europe Wants It
articles.snippet: Europe seemed to be doing so well, but now Italy is making the euro the center of a populist debate. Would Italians really leave the eurozone?
articles.abstract: Europe seemed to be doing so well, but now Italy is making the euro the center of a populist debate. Would Italians really leave the eurozone?
articles.lead_paragraph: LISBON — Through more than two months of tough negotiations to form a government in Italy after inconclusive March elections, global financial markets remained relatively calm. Italy’s uncertainties seemed contained to Italy, and Europe’s economy kept growing.

articles.headline: Battle to Stamp Out ISIS in Syria Gains New Momentum, but Threats Remain
articles.snippet: The return of top Syrian Kurdish commanders, a surge in French commandos, the arrival of Navy fighter jets and sleuthing by Iraqi spies have revived an effort that had stalled out.
articles.abstract: The return of top Syrian Kurdish commanders, a surge in French commandos, the arrival of Navy fighter jets and sleuthing by Iraqi spies have revived an effort that had stalled out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American-backed ground offensive to wipe out the last pockets of Islamic State fighters in eastern Syria has been reignited over the past month in an attempt to beat back the militants’ ability to wage guerrilla attacks.

articles.headline: For ‘Columbiners,’ School Shootings Have a Deadly Allure
articles.snippet: Many recent school shootings have in common that the perpetrators studied, and sometimes revered, their predecessors and tried to emulate or outdo them.
articles.abstract: Many recent school shootings have in common that the perpetrators studied, and sometimes revered, their predecessors and tried to emulate or outdo them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, Tex. — The exact reasons a teenage gunman shot his fellow students and teachers here at Santa Fe High School remain a mystery. His model for carrying it out is more clear.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Julie Turkewitz and Jess Bidgood

articles.headline: How a Pentagon Contract Became an Identity Crisis for Google
articles.snippet: A $9 million deal for the use of artificial intelligence technology has fractured the internet giant’s work force and risks driving away top engineering talent.
articles.abstract: A $9 million deal for the use of artificial intelligence technology has fractured the internet giant’s work force and risks driving away top engineering talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fei-Fei Li is among the brightest stars in the burgeoning field of artificial intelligence, somehow managing to hold down two demanding jobs simultaneously: head of Stanford University’s A.I. lab and chief scientist for A.I. at Google Cloud, one of the search giant’s most promising enterprises.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane, Cade Metz and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: In South Sudan, a Never-Ending Hunger Season Puts Millions in Danger
articles.snippet: The Times went to South Sudan to document the extent of hunger as food grew scarce. This year is expected to be the worst yet, as millions potentially face acute malnutrition.
articles.abstract: The Times went to South Sudan to document the extent of hunger as food grew scarce. This year is expected to be the worst yet, as millions potentially face acute malnutrition.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Times went to South Sudan to document the extent of hunger as food grew scarce. This year is expected to be the worst yet, as millions potentially face acute malnutrition.
articles.byline: By Megan Specia and Kassie Bracken

articles.headline: After Arkady Babchenko’s ‘Murder,’ a Twist Was Revealed. By Him.
articles.snippet: Ukraine says the death in Kiev of Arkady Babchenko was staged to thwart an assassination plot against him by Russia. It drew wide protests.
articles.abstract: Ukraine says the death in Kiev of Arkady Babchenko was staged to thwart an assassination plot against him by Russia. It drew wide protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The assassination bore all the hallmarks of yet another contract killing carried out in the murky shadows of the conflict pitting Russia against Ukraine.

articles.headline: Big Banks to Get a Break From Limits on Risky Trading
articles.snippet: The Fed proposed loosening the Volcker Rule, which prevents banks from trading with depositors’ money. The move is expected to give banks more room for complex trades.
articles.abstract: The Fed proposed loosening the Volcker Rule, which prevents banks from trading with depositors’ money. The move is expected to give banks more room for complex trades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big banks are getting a big reprieve from a postcrisis rule aimed at curbing risky behavior on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: The Privacy Lawyer Giving Big Tech an $8.8 Billion Headache
articles.snippet: With the enactment of new privacy rules in Europe, it isn’t just regulators going after Big Tech: Advocates like Max Schrems are already filing lawsuits.
articles.abstract: With the enactment of new privacy rules in Europe, it isn’t just regulators going after Big Tech: Advocates like Max Schrems are already filing lawsuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: At midnight last Friday, the European Union’s long-awaited new data-protection rules, known as the General Data Protection Regulation, officially kicked in.
